title-group.article-title: Phase stability and rapid consolidation of hydroxyapatite–zirconia nano-coprecipitates made using continuous hydrothermal flow synthesis

article-meta.aff: 1Christopher Ingold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, London, UK
2Interdisciplinary Research Centre in Biomedical Materials, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Lahore, Pakistan
3Centre for Materials Research and Nanoforce Technology Ltd., Queen Mary University of London, London, UK
4Division of Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering, UCL Eastman Dental Institute, London, UK
5WCU Research Centre of Nanobiomedical Science, Dankook University, Chungnam, South Korea
6The Kroto Research Institute, Department of Materials, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, UK

author-notes.corresp: Aqif A Chaudhry, Interdisciplinary Research Centre in Biomedical Materials, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Lahore, Pakistan Email: aqifanwar@ciitlahore.edu.pk

abstract.p: A rapid and continuous hydrothermal route for the synthesis of nano-sized hydroxyapatite rods co-precipitated with calcium-doped zirconia nanoparticles using a superheated water flow at 450°C and 24.1 MPa as a crystallizing medium is described. Hydroxyapatite and calcium-doped zirconia phases in the powder mixtures could be clearly identified based on particle size and morphology under transmission electron microscopy. Retention of a nanostructure after sintering is crucial to load-bearing applications of hydroxyapatite-based ceramics. Therefore, rapid consolidation of the co-precipitates was investigated using a spark plasma sintering furnace under a range of processing conditions. Samples nominally containing 5 and 10 wt% calcium-doped zirconia and hydroxyapatite made with Ca:P solution molar ratio 2.5 showed excellent thermal stability (investigated using in situ variable temperature X-ray diffraction) and were sintered via spark plasma sintering to >96% sintered densities at 1000°C resulting in hydroxyapatite and calcium-doped zirconia as the only two phases. Mechanical tests of spark plasma sintering sintered samples (containing 10 wt% calcium-doped zirconia) revealed a three-pt flexural strength of 107.7 MPa and Weibull modulus of 9.9. The complementary nature of the spark plasma sintering technique and continuous hydrothermal flow synthesis (which results in retention of a nanostructure even after sintering at elevated temperatures) was hence showcased.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hydroxyapatite (HA, Ca10(OH)2(PO4)6) has been utilised, as a reinforcement in biomedical polymers, as a coating on metallic implants and as a scaffold material for bone growth due to its chemical similarity to the mineral component of bone.1–4 Indeed, HA granules have found success in hard-tissue surgery as they are bioactive, relatively insoluble and able to bond to surrounding natural tissue.5,6 However, because of its inferior mechanical properties (low wear resistance, flexural strength etc.), the use of HA is usually limited to low load bearing areas of the human body (e.g. ossicles in the middle ear).7 In order to overcome the mechanical limitations of HA, composites incorporating either zirconia, alumina, titania particles, carbon or stainless steel fibre have been used.8–13 Mostly, large additions of these reinforcing ceramics are required to yield a significant increase in mechanical performance, for example high flexural strength of ca. 250 MPa can be achieved with zirconia additives.14 In most cases, this also requires high sintering temperatures and long heat-treatment times. However, small ZrO2 additions (ca. 1.5 wt%) to HA powders have been shown to significantly improve bending strength (three-pt) of dense discs (going from 183 to 243 MPa after the addition).14 ZrO2-HA formulations have, therefore, been exploited as robust coatings for biomedical applications.15,16

HA–ZrO2 ceramic composites are normally sintered from mixtures of separately synthesised HA and ZrO2 powders17–24 or from co-precipitated powders (which can be a slow process).25–32 A room temperature co-precipitation method has been reported to result in homogeneously mixed particles of ZrO2 and HA, which are readily compacted and sintered (1100°C) up to 40 vol.% of ZrO2.33

The sintering or densification of HA containing powders has been the subject of considerable literature.7,20,34–39 Conventionally, consolidation is carried out using pressure-less sintering or hot-pressing. Pressure-less sintering usually involves sintering at high temperatures (above 1200°C) for up to 4 h.36,40–47 HA–ZrO2 powders have also been densified via pressure-less sintering (up to 1500°C and 4 h)7,17–19,22,31,37,48–50 and hot-pressing (up to 1225°C, 160 MPa).23,26,51–55 The high temperatures and long sintering periods often required for these methods, result in grain sizes up to a several microns (HA up to 5 µm, ZrO2 up to 3 µm).31 Ideally, if smaller grain sizes could be obtained for defect-free HA and HA–ZrO2 composites (while retaining high density), they would be expected to show superior mechanical performance (flexural strength, hardness, wear resistance etc.).9

Recently, consolidation of ceramics using spark plasma sintering (SPS) has gained importance due to the speed of this method and ability to control grain size growth.56 In SPS, a pulsed DC current directly passes through a graphite die, as well as the powder compact. Heated samples can be rapidly sintered (in a few minutes) under pressure using rapid heating and cooling rates resulting in nanostructured ceramics in selected cases.57 Indeed, consolidation of HA to very high density has been carried out using SPS.58–65 High-density (95%–100% of theoretical density) HA disks were produced via SPS at 900–1100°C under a pressure of 63–120 MPa. The mechanical properties (85–110 MPa for three-pt flexural strength and 5–6 GPa for Vickers hardness) of the SPS-treated HA was higher compared to muffle furnace–sintered HA.58,59 There have been reports of ZrO2-HA ceramics sintered using SPS at temperatures and sintering times as low as 1000°C and 5 min.20,21,66–68 In one such report, the Vickers hardness and flexural strength for HA was 5.4 GPa and 94 MPa, while for ZrO2 it was 14.2 GPa and 929 MPa, respectively.68 Miao and co-workers reported a three-pt flexural strength of 200 MPa for 40 wt% yttria stabilised zirconia (YSZ) in HA. The composite was prepared by SPS to 93% theoretical density in 5 min at 1200°C and the HA grain size did not exceed 1 µm.67

The continuous hydrothermal flow synthesis (CHFS) technique is fast gaining popularity due to its ability to synthesise crystalline nano-sized particles rapidly.69–78 In previous publications by the authors, the CHFS of phase-pure and ion doped calcium phosphates and SPS of apatites synthesised using CHFS technology was reported.56,79,80 As the CHFS method can produce a very small grain size and intimately mixed HA and other phases, rapid consolidation to retain a small grain size via SPS could offer access to dense nanostructured ceramics containing only calcium-doped zirconia (CDZ) and HA with no thermal decomposition products. In this study, the co-precipitation and co-crystallization of HA and CDZ mixtures (with varying ZrO2 contents) in the CHFS system and their subsequent consolidation using an SPS furnace was investigated. The thermal stability and mechanical properties of selected samples were also investigated.

sec.title: Materials and equipment
sec.p: Diammonium hydrogen phosphate [(NH4)2HPO4, 98.3%] supplied by Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Company (Dorset, UK) was used as a phosphate ion (PO43−) source. Calcium nitrate tetrahydrate [Ca(NO3)2·4H2O, 99%] supplied by Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Company (Dorset, UK) was used as a calcium ion (Ca2+) source. All aqueous solutions for the CHFS were made using 10 MΩ deionised water. Where required, aqueous ammonia (ca. 16.9 mol·L−1) supplied by VWR International (UK) was used to adjust the solutions’ pH (sold as 30% w/w). Zirconyl nitrate hexahydrate [ZrO(NO3)2·6H2O] supplied by Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Company (Dorset, UK) was used as a source of zirconia (ZrO2). Potassium hydroxide (KOH, 90%) was supplied by VWR International (UK).

Samples were freeze-dried using a Virtis Advantage Freeze Dryer, Model 2.0 ES, supplied by BioPharma (Winchester, UK). The centrifuged slurries were placed in a freezer at −5°C for 1 h and then freeze-dried for 22 h at 1.3 × 10−7 MPa. A JEOL 2010 Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM; 200 kV accelerating voltage) was used for generating images of particles. Elemental analyses were performed using an Oxford Instruments Inca 400 EDS (Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectrometer) detector attached to JEOL 5410 LVSEM. An X-pert Pro PW3064/60 diffractometer with a high-throughput stage was used for collection of X-ray diffraction patterns. Continuous scans were collected over the 2θ range 5–120° with a step size of 0.03° for 200 s per step. A Brüker D8 Advance diffractometer with a Ni filtered Cu-Kα radiation and a Lynx Eye detector was used to study in situ phase behaviour of HA–ZrO2 samples as a function of temperature. To perform the high temperature experiments, an Anton Paar HTK16 heating stage with an Anton Paar TCU 2000 control unit was used, integrated with the Brüker control software. The as-precipitated powders were placed on a platinum heater stage. The temperature was measured using a R-type thermocouple welded to the bottom of the platinum heater strip (temperature accuracy ±1 K). After sealing, the platinum heater enclosure was purged with air at a 2 mL·min−1 flow rate. The sample was heated at 10°C·min−1 up to 1200°C. Data were collected over 2θ ranges of 21–36° and 48–52° with a step size of 0.02 and a count time of 1 s after 50° intervals. During collection, the sample temperature was kept constant. Brauner-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area measurements (using N2 gas adsorption method) were performed on a Micromeritics Gemini analyser. The powders were first degassed at 110°C for 3 h prior to analyses. SPS furnace (FCT System HPD 25/1) was used to consolidate the powders. For the three-pt flexural strength testing, two 40-mm diameter spark plasma sintered discs were cut using a diamond cutter into five or six specimens (per disc) with rectangular cross-sections. The final average dimensions of the 10 rectangular specimens tested was ca. 25 × 3 × 2 mm. The tests were carried out using Instron 8511.20 at a loading rate of 500 N·min−1. This corresponded to a strain rate of ∼0.2 mm·min−1. Prior to testing, all samples were pre-loaded at 2.0 N force. The three-pt flexural strength was determined using the ASTM standard C1161. The fractured surfaces of the sintered (SPS) discs were gold-coated and observed using an FEI inspect-F scanning electron microscope. The linearization method was adopted for the determination of Weibull modulus.81

sec.title: Synthesis and methodology
sec.p: CDZ-HA mixtures were synthesised using a CHFS reactor that is identical to that reported elsewhere by the authors.56,79,80 Two different Ca:P molar ratios were used in the solutions (1.67 and 2.5). In total, seven CHFS reactions were carried out for this study.

sec.title: Synthesis of CDZ-HA mixtures
sec.p: For a solution Ca:P ratio of 1.67, two identical 83.5 mM calcium nitrate solutions were prepared. Different amounts of zirconyl nitrate (hydrated) were added to both these solutions such that they would result in 25 wt% and 50 wt% ZrO2 (nominal) in HA based on 100% theoretical yields. A 50.0 mM stock solution of diammonium hydrogen phosphate (adjusted to pH 10 using ammonium hydroxide) was used. These samples are labelled as L-25 and L-50 (where L represents a lower Ca:P molar ratio of 1.67 and the number represents the nominal weight percentage of zirconia in the mixture).

For a Ca:P solution ratio of 2.5, four identical solutions of 125.0 mM calcium nitrate were prepared. Zirconyl nitrate was added to each of these four calcium nitrate solutions separately (pH 2 for all four solutions). These corresponded to 5, 10, 25 and 75 wt% (nominal) ZrO2 in HA, respectively. A stock solution of 50.0 mM diammonium hydrogen phosphate solution (adjusted to pH 10 using ammonium hydroxide solution) was used. These samples are labelled as H-5, H-10, H-25 and H-50 (where H represents a higher Ca:P molar ratio of 2.5 and the number represents the nominal weight percentage of zirconia in the mixture). An additional sample was prepared by dissolving calcium nitrate and zirconyl nitrate together to result in an overall 400 mM concentration (pH 2). This sample is labelled as H-100.

The CHFS system used (see Figure 1 for schematic) was similar to that reported earlier by the authors.56,79,80 Gilson 25SC pump heads were used with all the three Gilson (HPLC) pumps. The calcium nitrate and diammonium hydrogen phosphate solutions were both pumped at 12.5 mL·min−1 to meet at a 1/8″ 316SS Swagelok™ T-piece and immediately form a suspension. Water was pumped through the pre-heater at 25 mL·min−1 to arrive at a counter-current mixer where it met the flowing suspension and caused rapid crystallisation of amorphous apatitic phases (combined flow rate was 50 mL·min−1). The 3/8″ counter-current mixer was made using 3/8″ 316SS Swagelok™ parts as described elsewhere.56,79,80 In order to maintain a high temperature at the mixing point, a 200 W Watlow band heater (2.5 cm diameter and in thermal contact with the 3/8″ steel tube via an aluminium sleeve) was used on the outside of the counter-current mixer and set to 450 °C. This gave a reaction temperature of ca. 310°C at a thermocouple placed just above the counter-current mixer, which can be assumed to be close to the reaction temperature. Our results showed that use of a band heater on the counter-current mixing point was beneficial for maximising yields and enabling reactions to proceed closer to completion.69 The theoretical yield of HA (based on 1.67 Ca:P molar ratio) for a 83.5 mM calcium nitrate solution was calculated to be ∼8.4 g. In this work, for ∼1 h of CHFS reaction ∼8 g of HA powder were readily obtained after centrifugation and freeze-drying (yield >95%). This compares to ca. <4 g (up to ca. 48% yield) of HA for synthesis conditions mentioned in an earlier publication by the authors (20 mL·min−1 combined flow rate, 400°C synthesis temperature, no band heater on the counter-current mixing point).79 Figure 1.
Scheme of the three-pump continuous hydrothermal flow synthesis system used for the preparation of nano HA–ZrO2. Key: P = HPLC pump, H = heater (set to 450°C), R = counter-current mixer, T = stainless steel T-piece mixer. Band heater on counter-current mixer is omitted for clarity. HA: hydroxyapatite; HPLC: high-performance liquid chromatography.

sec.title: Spark plasma sintering
sec.p: Samples for SPS were accurately weighed and placed into a 20 mm diameter graphite die (40 mm diameter die was used for discs for three-pt flexural strength determination). Graphite paper was used to line the inner surface of the die and the surfaces below and above the inserted hydroxyapatite powder. The graphite die was then press-sealed manually using a Perkin Elmer hydraulic press. The press-sealed die was then placed in the heating chamber of the SPS furnace and heated up to the desired temperature at 200°C·min−1. Force was applied on all the samples during sintering such that it always resulted in 100 MPa pressure. Cooling rates were varied (along with pressure during cooling) in order to obtain crack-free discs. After sintering, the graphite die was allowed to cool down in the furnace to room temperature prior to extraction. The sample was extracted from the die using the manual hydraulic press. The surfaces of the discs were ground and polished in order to remove the carbon residue on the surface. This revealed a white polished surface suggesting little or no contamination. Indeed, SPS has been reported to result in carbon contamination free ceramics.82 The sintered densities were measured using the Archimedes’s method and are reported as a percentage of the theoretical density of HA (i.e. 3.16 g·cm−3).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Transmission electron microscopy was used to analyse the particle size and morphology of samples L-25 and L-50 as shown in Figure 2(a) to (f). It was observed that HA and CDZ particles largely retained their independent morphologies. Figure 2(a) and (b) revealed distinct rods of HA [271 (±75) × 57 (±19) nm: 100 particles sampled] and agglomerated CDZ (sample L-25) nanoparticles (<10 nm). The HA rods produced in the presence of CDZ were considerably longer compared to pure HA made via CHFS [166 (± 62) × 39 (±14) nm] in a previous report by the authors using identical synthesis, pressure and flow rates.56 HA rods for sample L-50 were measured to be 302 (±247) × 64 (±21) nm (100 particles sampled). The large standard deviation in average length was due to some extremely long HA rods (length range ca. 250–1000 nm) as seen in Figure 2(c). HA whiskers have been reported in literature to precipitate in hydrothermal conditions in the presence of acetamide.83 In the current case this was possibly due to preferential growth of HA in the [001] direction due to surface stabilisation by CDZ particles. Figure 2(f) revealed CDZ particles of sample L-50 to be ca. 5.0 (±1.6) nm in diameter (100 particles sampled). Figure 2.
Transmission electron microscope images of sample L-25 at (a) ×25 k magnification (bar = 200 nm), (b) ×50 k magnification (bar = 100 nm) and sample L-50 at (c) ×25 k magnification (bar = 200 nm), (d) ×50 k magnification (bar = 100 nm), (e) ×100 k magnification (bar = 50 nm) and (f) ×200 k magnification (bar = 20 nm).

The BET technique (N2 adsorption) was used to measure the specific surface areas of all powders (as shown in Figure 3). Sample L-25 and L-50 had BET surface areas of 82 (±2) and 165 (±2) m2·g−1, respectively. Samples H-5, H-10, H-25 and H-50 had surface area of 41 (±2), 54 (±2), 95 (±3) and 177 (±3) m2·g−1, respectively. The surface area of sample H-5 [41 (±2) m2·g−1] was much higher than that of phase-pure HA [22 (±2) m2·g−1] made under similar conditions.56 This strongly suggested the presence of some CDZ (also supported by elemental analyses data shown in supplementary Table S1). It was also noticed that the increase in BET surface area with amount of CDZ in the as-precipitated mixture was linear (with ca. 0.99 of R2 value for both trends). This is understandable because CDZ has a much higher surface area than HA. It was also observed that a higher in solution Ca:P molar ratio, resulted in higher surface area of the as-precipitated mixtures as represented by the difference in the solid and dotted line in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Increase in BET surface area mixed HA/CDZ powders with weight percent of ZrO2 (calculated using EDS) in as-precipitated samples for in-solution Ca/P molar ratio of (♦) 2.5(solid line) and (•) 1.67 (dotted line). CDZ: calcium-doped zirconia; HA: hydroxyapatite.

Powder X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of all as-precipitated samples are shown in Figure 4(a) to (f). The peaks marked with a solid circle correspond to crystalline HA (good match to ICDD pattern 09-432) and the peaks marked with a triangle gave a good match to both tetragonal zirconia and cubic calcium stabilised zirconia, Ca0.15Zr0.85O1.85 (ICDD patterns 42-1164 and 26-341, respectively). It has been reported that differentiation between cubic and tetragonal phases of zirconia is difficult based on XRD alone, however, Raman spectroscopy is an effective method to distinguish between these polymorphs.84 Supplementary Figure S1 shows the Raman spectra for the powdered samples. The peak around 487 cm−1 [see Figure S1 (a)–(f)] was attributed to the presence of tetragonal CDZ. Peaks at ca. 641, 613, 473, 325, 260 and 146 cm−1 have been reported previously for tetragonal zirconia in the literature.84,85 Figure 4(g) shows the XRD diffraction pattern for sample H-100, which corresponded to phase pure (cubic or tetragonal) CDZ. The CDZ peaks were broad and of relatively low intensities in Figure 4(b) to (g). This was attributed to the small size of zirconia particles (average diameter <10 nm, as shown in Figure 2(f)). It was observed that the most intense CDZ peak centred at ca. 30.5° was not observed in the XRD plot for sample H-5 (Figure 4(a)), which was possibly due to the low phase proportion of CDZ in the mixture. Although differentiation between the cubic and tetragonal polymorphs of zirconia is difficult via XRD alone, evidence in the literature suggests that particle sizes below ca. 20 nm can stabilise the tetragonal phase.85 Figure 4.
Powder X-ray diffraction patterns for as-precipitated samples (a) H-5 (b) H-10 (c) L-25 (d) H-25 (e) L-50 (f) H-50 and (g) H-100. Key: ▾ = Zr1-xCaxO2-y, • = HA. HA: hydroxyapatite.

Selected nanopowder samples were consolidated using SPS at 900°C and 1000°C, except sample H-100, which was only sintered via SPS at 1000°C. In order to avoid cracking that may arise due to high content of HA, samples H-5 and H-10 were SPS sintered for 5 min and 15 s, while for the rest of the samples, 5 min of sintering period were applied. The additional time in the case of samples H-5 and H-10 was required for unloading the samples (this was observed to result in crack-free discs). The densities (in g·cm−3) were measured using the Archimedes method and the relevant data and SPS conditions are summarised in Table 1. It was observed for the most of the cases, a higher density was obtained at 1000°C for each sample. Table 1.
Sample IDs, calculated theoretical densities, SPS sintering temperatures and times and measured densities of HA-CDZ and CDZ-sintered discs.
Sample ID Theoretical density (g·cm−3) Sintering conditions Measured density
Temp (°C) Time (min:sec) (g·cm−3) (%)
H-5 3.25 900 5:15 3.10 (±0.07) 95.3 (±2.2)
1000 5:15 3.08 (±0.08) 94.7 (±2.4)
H-10 3.34 900 5:15 2.98 (±0.04) 89.3 (±3.0)
1000 5:15 3.30 (±0.03) 98.8 (±0.9)
L-25 3.59 900 5:00 2.78 (±0.04) 77.4 (±1.2)
1000 5:00 3.42 (±0.04) 95.1 (±1.1)
H-25 3.65 900 5:00 3.02 (±0.08) 82.6 (±2.2)
1000 5:00 3.48 (±0.10) 95.4 (±2.7)
L-50 4.16 900 5:00 3.08 (±0.11) 74.0 (±2.6)
1000 5:00 3.79 (±0.07) 91.1 (±1.6)
H-50 4.22 900 5:00 3.12 (±0.09) 74.0 (±2.2)
1000 5:00 3.80 (±0.05) 90.1 (±1.3)
H-100a 5.55 1000 5:00 3.19 (±0.17) 57.6 (±3.1)
CDZ: calcium-doped zirconia; HA: hydroxyapatite; SPS: spark plasma sintering; ZrO2: zirconia. a
Sample HA-100 s density of 5.50 g·cm−3 was taken from unit cell details of the ICDD pattern 26-341. The calculated densities assume mixtures of HA and ZrO2 only.

Figure 5(a) to (m) shows the XRD patterns of spark plasma sintered discs from the as-precipitated nanopowders (the corresponding powder XRD patterns are shown in Figure 4). X-ray diffraction patterns of sample H-5 sintered at 900°C and 1000°C (shown in Figure 5(a) and (b)) revealed only two phases, phase-pure HA and CDZ (similar to ICDD patterns 26-341 for cubic Ca0.15O1.85Zr0.85 and 42-1164 for tetragonal ZrO2). Similarly, XRD patterns for sample H-10 sintered at 900°C or 1000°C, revealed only phase-pure HA and CDZ (Figure 5(c) and (d)). The intensity of the main CDZ peak at 30.5° increased with increasing CDZ content and sintering (SPS) temperature (potentially attributed to higher crystallinity and larger grains). Sample L-25 sintered at 900°C also resulted in phase-pure CDZ and HA (Figure 5(e)). Figure 5.
Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of sample, H-5 spark plasma sintered at (a) 900°C and (b) 1000°C, sample H-10 sintered (SPS) at (c) 900°C and (d) 1000°C, sample L-25 sintered (SPS) at (e) 900°C and (f) 1000°C, sample H-25 sintered (SPS) at (g) 900°C and (h) 1000°C, sample L-50 sintered (SPS) at (i) 900°C and (j) 1000°C, H-50 sintered (SPS) at (k) 900°C and (l) 1000°C and (m) sample H-100 sintered (SPS) at 1000°C. Key: • = HA, = Monoclinic ZrO2, ♦ = β-TCP, ▾ = CDZ, ▪ = CaZrO3. CDZ: calcium-doped zirconia; HA: hydroxyapatite; SPS: spark plasma sintering.

When sample L-25 was sintered (SPS) at 1000°C, the XRD pattern suggested a small amount of a third phase β-TCP (matching ICDD pattern 9-169) as shown in Figure 5(f). Sample L-25 was synthesized using an in-solution Ca:P molar ratio of ca. 1.67 (stoichiometric ratio). Appearance of β-TCP was possibly due to calcium uptake by the zirconia phase either during CHFS synthesis or during sintering rendering the apatitic phase calcium deficient; hence susceptible to formation of β-TCP phase above 750°C.86 On the other hand, sample H-25 (similar CDZ content to L-25 but with an in-solution Ca:P molar ratio of ca. 2.5) sintered at 900°C and 1000°C yielded phase-pure CDZ and HA only, as shown in Figure 5(g) and (h), respectively. Summarily, for a nominal composition of 25 wt% CDZ and 75 wt% HA, an in-solution Ca:P molar ratio of 2.5, results in a thermally stable HA phase (up to 1000°C after SPS). X-ray diffraction patterns of discs sintered from samples H-5 and H-10 in the 900–1000°C range (Figure 5(a) to (d)) did not reveal any TCP phase, due to a higher in-solution Ca:P molar ratio of ca. 2.5.

Sample L-50 sintered at 900°C consisted mainly of CDZ and HA as shown in Figure 5(i) (a small peak corresponding to Beta tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP) was also observed). Additionally, a very small peak at 31.8° (2θ) corresponding to calcium zirconate, CaZrO3 (similar to ICDD pattern 35-079), partially obscured by the main HA peak was also observed. When sample L-50 was sintered (SPS) at 1000°C, the β-TCP and CaZrO3 peaks increased in relative intensity compared to the HA peaks (Figure 5(j)). This suggested a solid-state reaction between HA and CDZ to form CaZrO3.

Sample H-50 sintered (SPS) at 900°C revealed mainly HA and CDZ peaks as shown in Figure 5(k). Very small peaks corresponding to β-TCP and CaZrO3 were also observed (similar behaviour to L-50 at 900°C). However, H-50 sintered at 1000°C had a composition of mainly HA and CDZ as well, which is in contrast to L-50 sintered at the same temperature (Figure 5(l)). This suggested that a higher Ca:P solution ratio during CHFS synthesis of powders made HA more thermally stable in an SPS furnace and decreased the amount of CaZrO3 formed at 1000°C.

Figure 5(m) shows the XRD pattern for sample H-100 sintered at 1000°C in which peaks corresponding to CDZ (either cubic or tetragonal) and CaZrO3 were observed. A small peak for monoclinic CDZ (similar to ICDD pattern 37-1484) was also observed. Referring to the equilibrium phase diagram for calcia (CaO) and zirconia (ZrO2) mixture and considering sample H-100 has a calcium content of 26 mol.% with respect to zirconium, it is not surprising that calcium zirconate is formed at 1000°C.87

The thermal phase stability of selected samples was investigated using in situ variable temperature X-ray diffraction (VT-XRD). Figures 6 and 7 show the two-dimensional (2D) VT-XRD contour map and the three-dimensional (3D) VT-XRD pattern, respectively, for sample H-50. HA peaks decreased in intensity above ca. 650°C, disappearing at 1000°C. In comparison the VT-XRD data for sample L-50 (supplementary Figures S2 and S3), revealed that HA peaks last appeared at a lower temperature (ca. 860°C). Upon cooling of samples H-50 and L-50, peaks corresponding to CDZ, α-TCP and CaZrO3 were observed (not shown), however, the amount of CaZrO3 formed for H-50 was seemingly lower. This suggested that a higher Ca:P molar ratio used in solution improved the thermal stability of HA and retarded the solid state reaction that led to CaZrO3. The VT-XRD data for other selected samples (H-5 and H-10) are given in supplementary Figures S4 to S7 with a supplementary discussion. Figure 6.
2D XRD contour map of sample H-50 (temperature versus 2θ) showing appearance and disappearance of peaks with increasing temperature. 2D: two-dimensional; XRD: X-ray powder diffraction. Figure 7.
3D VT-XRD plot of intensity versus 2θ angle (°) versus temperature (°C) for sample H-50. 3D: three-dimensional; XRD: X-ray powder diffraction.

Figure 8(a) to (c) shows scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of the fractured surfaces of sample H-10 sintered (SPS) at 1000°C. Figure 8(a) shows a non-porous region of the sintered disc with sub-micron features at ×100 k magnification. Figure 8(b) to (c) shows an adjacent, slightly porous region of the sample. In Figure 8(c) two distinct grain sizes were clearly visible, the larger grains (average 210 nm (±40); 100 grains sampled) are likely to be HA, whereas the considerably smaller grains (average 48 nm (±12); 100 grains sampled) are likely to be CDZ. In Figure 8(b), a few grains (marked on the figure) were observed to have a rod-like particle morphology akin to that of HA prior to sintering. In comparison with the spark plasma sintered HA nanostructure presented in an earlier publication by the authors,56 it seems presence of CDZ nanoparticles (a higher temperature sintering phase) prevented the HA grains from coalescing completely under SPS. The density of the H-10 disc was measured to be ca. 96% using the Archimedes’s method. Figure 8.
SEM images of sample H-10 sintered at 1000°C for 5 min 15 s at magnification (a) ×100 k [bar = 1 µm] (b) × 100 k [bar = 1 µm] (c) × 100 k [bar = 1 µm] and (d) ×189 k [bar = 500 nm]. SEM: scanning electron microscope.

The flexural strength of sample H-10 (SPS at 1000°C) was measured as 107.7 MPa (±10.2) and a Weibull modulus of 9.9 was obtained (refer to supplementary Table S2 and Figure S8). This is significantly higher (and sintering time and temperature are significantly lower) when compared to a three-pt flexural strength of 37 MPa for 10 wt% zirconia in HA sintered conventially (green body pressed uniaxially followed by pressureless sintering) at 1250°C for 4 h.88 However, this value is lower than what might be expected when compared to the recently reported high flexural strength of 158.4 MPa for pure HA (made from SPS of CHFS made nano-HA).56 Evidently, the presence of CDZ particles on the surfaces of the HA rods under these conditions prevents the HA particles from sintering completely, however, the strength achieved is significantly higher than conventional sintering methods mainly due to retention of a nanostructure despite exposure to an elevated temperature.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: HA rods (aspect ratios up to 5) were co-precipitated and co-crystallized with CDZ in a CHFS system using a supercritical water feed at 450°C and 24.1 MPa (with a mixing point band heater set at 450°C). A tetragonal crystal structure was suggested for CDZ in the powder mixtures. In situ VT-XRD results indicated samples containing 5 and 10 wt% CDZ and HA made with a Ca:P solution molar ratio of 2.5 (H-5 and H-10) to be ideal samples in terms of thermal stability up to 1000°C compared to samples synthesized at lower Ca:P solution ratios (wherein formation of the mechanically deleterious phase CaZrO3 was avoided). Indeed, samples H-5 and H-10 were sintered to ca. 98% and 96% sintered densities, respectively, at 1000°C resulting in HA and CDZ as the only two phases. The flexural strength of sample H-10 was 107.7 MPa, which is higher than reports on conventionally sintered ceramics in literature.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work has been jointly sponsored by EPSRC (The Continuous Hydrothermal Synthesis of Nanomaterials: From Laboratory to Pilot Plant project (EP/E040551/1), a Higher Education Commission (HEC) of Pakistan scholarship (AAC), Sun Chemicals and WCU Program (JCK) through the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) funded by the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology (No. R31-10069).

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Nicky Mordan (Eastman Dental Institute, UCL) is thanked for her help with EDS (SEM). Mick Willis and Zofia Luklinska (NanoVision Centre, QMUL) are thanked for their help with TEM.
